abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Tuli Block Roads Project
            for Botswana were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory,
            project sustainability was likely, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was also a
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:  insufficient
            supervision cannot enhance sector policy dialog and
            partnership. The project implementation becomes difficult
            when a key component is affected by ministries other than
            the implementing agency. It is difficult to evaluate
            institutional capacity where no performance indicators were
            established. Botswana is a case where regional
            considerations need to be negotiated before setting up any
            project and sector specific policy on the country basis.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Tuli Block Roads Project is a
            natural continuation of the Bank's support directed
            towards eliminating the major constraints to the area's
            emerging economic attraction to investors and will build on
            previous Bank involvement in the road subsector by
            strengthening the planning and maintenance capability of the
            Roads Department.  The main objectives of the project are to
            : a) provide road links necessary for the development and
            integration of the Selebi-Phikwe area and its hinterland; b)
            strengthen the capacity of the RD to organize and carry out
            effective road maintenance at the increased level mandated
            by the expansion of the road network; and c) improve road
            planning and programming capability in anticipation of the
            seventh National Development Plan in 1991. Project
            components comprise the following : 1) construction of the
            Sefophe-Martin's Drift road, 134 km, to bitumen
            standard, and village access roads; 2) construction of the
            Bobonong-Lekkerpoet road, 66 km, including two short access
            roads to the villages of Molalatau and Mathathane; and 3)
            consulting services for construction supervision and for
            preparation of a study for a new maintenance management /
            organization system for roads, combined with a network
            planning study.

repnme.cdata!:
Botswana - Tuli Block Roads Project :
            Sefophe-Martin's Drift Road - environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental impact statement
            concerns the predetermined centre-line for the
            Sefophe-Martin's Drift Road, a component of the Tuli
            Block Roads Project in Botswana. While the impact on the
            natural environment by the development will be high during
            the construction phase, this can be justified by the
            socio-economic benefits over the long term. High adverse
            impacts and their ameliorations include: a) geology &
            soils - the removal of materials for road building, topsoil,
            and vegetation cover, and use of crusher stone hill;
            ameliorated by concurrent rehabilitation and erosion
            management; b) surface hydrology - stream bed changes due to
            bridge construction; ameliorated by minimizing run-off and
            siltation; c) fauna - increased road accidents and drinking
            holes; ameliorated by fencing of road and water source
            management; d) flora - vegetation removal, dust, and bridge
            construction; ameliorated by limiting work area size,
            protecting special vegetation, and concurrent
            rehabilitation; e) depopulation of villages; ameliorated by
            broad Regional Plan for Development; and f) noise & dust
            pollution; ameliorated by damping down during construction.
